title: 114_hr4905
content: The "ATF Enforcement Act" eliminates the Senate confirmation requirement for the appointment of the Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. It also removes limitations related to firearms trace data. The Tiahrt Amendments amend provisions related to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives' salaries and expenses in certain appropriations acts. The Tiahrt Amendments modify provisions regarding the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives' salaries and expenses in specific appropriations acts by specifying fiscal year 2009 instead of "thereafter" and fiscal year 2008 instead of "thereafter". The Tiahrt Amendments modify provisions in specific appropriations acts by specifying fiscal year 2009 and fiscal year 2008 instead of "thereafter". Amendments include repealing sections related to the use of firearms trace data to draw broad conclusions about firearms-related crime. SEC. 4 amends the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2012 by removing a proviso related to firearms acquisition and disposition records. SEC. 5 eliminates the prohibition on requiring firearms dealers to conduct physical checks of their inventory. The Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2013 is amended to eliminate the requirement for instant check records to be destroyed within 24 hours. Additionally, the prohibition on processing Freedom of Information Act requests about arson, explosives incidents, or firearm traces is removed. Section 644 of division J of the Consolidated Appropriations Resolution, 2003 is repealed, along with various prohibitions related to curios or relics and surplus military firearms importation. Additionally, sections 518 and 519 of division B of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016 and 2013 are repealed, and a prohibition on denial of federal firearms license due to lack of business activity is eliminated. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2013 and 2016 are amended to remove certain prohibitions related to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The functions of the bureau can now be transferred to other agencies or departments, and the search of computerized records of federally licensed firearms dealers who are out of business is no longer prohibited. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2013 and 2016 amended provisions related to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives. The recent changes include the elimination of a prohibition on denying certain shotgun imports based on sporting purposes and the repeal of a section in the 2016 Appropriations Act.
